segments.text: Happy Friday.
Welcome to Fearless with Jason Whitlock.
I am Jason Whitlock, the captain of this, I guess I'm the general of the Fearless Army.
The weekend is here, baby, and I'm going to send this off into the weekend with an absolute
banging show.
Look, Delano Squires, there's a reason I call him the smartest man on the show.
I think it was yesterday or the day before I was joking with Chamika.
Like, oh, I think she's trying to take the title from Delano, and Delano probably overheard
that comment or was told about that comment.
And so you know what Delano did?
He wrote the best column in my view that he's ever written for the blaze.
And so it's a tremendous column.
I'm going to get into it with Delano, and it's his explanation about being a black conservative
and what his agenda is.
As a black conservative, you're accused of a lot of different things.
And basically, his agenda is expressing a biblical worldview, period into story.
And I read this and I was like, is he ghost writing?
My own thoughts?
And that's not why I thought it was tremendous, but it was just so concise, so unclear, so
on point that we're going to start the show, talking with the smartest man on the show,
Delano Squires.
But the second half of the show will be just as good.
We're going to bring on Ethan Strauss.
He does a sub-stack called the House of Strauss.
He made his bones as an NBA writer covering the Golden State Warriors.
He's worked at ESPN.
He's worked for the Athletic.
He's now struck out on his own.
And Ethan Strauss writes some of the best, most thought-provoking stuff you can find on
the internet as it relates to the sports world.
Ethan Strauss is tremendous.
He wrote a piece last week about a week ago breaking down the Adrian Warginowski, Brian
Windhorse feud over at ESPN, over the James Harden, Ben Simmons trade, Kerfoffel or whatever.
Who's going to break the news?
It's a tremendous piece on Adrian Warginowski and what's really going on in the sports media
landscape.
Ethan Strauss is a big thinker, a big writer, and he also writes some very provocative stuff
about LeBron James will get into.
He wrote a piece in late December, I believe it was, where he talked about why LeBron James
isn't connecting the way LeBron James wants to, off the court, in pursuit of being the
Muhammad Ali of this generation.
We'll get into all that and more with Ethan Strauss.
You do not want to miss the Ethan Strauss interview.
Great stuff on ESPN and Adrian Warginowski and some real inside sports media stuff that
you'll find very fascinating.
Then we'll get into a conversation about LeBron James.
But we're actually going to start today's show.
Delano has started such a massive huge fire with his own column that we're going to go
straight out to Washington DC and bring in the smartest man on the show and have a
full, throaty conversation about the piece that he wrote today, the first paragraph of
the piece.
One of the most fascinating and frustrating things about being a black person with views
described as conservative is the constant assumption that you're trying to advance a
nefarious self-serving agenda.
Delano, I don't know if I can do an explanation of your column justice.
I almost just want to sit back and let you read it on air.
But man, I just, I thought this piece was tremendous.
So much of it relates to me when I, two weeks ago, I had a conversation with a very good
friend of mine who lives out in New York.
He's mixed race.
He's half Puerto Rican, half white.
And I was trying to explain, he thinks there's some great advantage in seeing both sides.
And you know, Jason, you don't criticize both sides the way you're used to.
And I'm like, nothing's changed with me, man.
I have a biblical worldview and there just happens to be one side of the group that seems
far more out of alignment with God and his will for us than the other side.
And so I just keep pointing out, like, hey, man, this isn't consistent with my biblical
worldview.
Anyway, I don't want to distract from that.
Please give us an explanation, a summation of your column today.
Sure.
Again, thank you for having me on, Jason.
I was motivated to write this because during the past week when I've been going back and
forth with some folks about hip hop and its contributions to American society, and particularly
the black culture, some person responded to me that my contention that hip hop has normalized
and glorified, commodified violence among black men and the degradation of black women, he
said, this is a lie and indicative of someone with an agenda.
Now as usual, he didn't offer any counter, no substantive argument.
It rarely ever is.
And my first reflex was to defend myself, and so I don't have an agenda.
But I thought about it.
I said, no, I actually do have an agenda.
And I want to apply maximum pressure in the culture, in the policy space, online, wherever
I go to advance that agenda.
And that agenda, and I said it in the piece, is fairly straightforward, is to apply a
biblical worldview to matters of policy and culture in order to affirm the human dignity
and the inherent sense of worth that is in all of us as people, black, white, regardless
of our race, color, ethnicity, because we are created beings, because we are created
by God.
This is really a Genesis 127 agenda, where it says that man is created in the image of
God, and it lays out that God is creator, that God created male and female, and that
each of us is stamped with the Latin terms, the Imago dei, so that sense of dignity and
worth because of who created us, not what we look like, not what we can do.
And this is why my positions, I can write about anything from slavery, abortion, sex
work, criticize hip hop, because all of those things make human worth and value conditional
on what a particular individual can do in service of another, or what a particular individual
keeps another from doing.
So for me, I just wanted to say that clearly, and as it relates to race, I go through different
groups.
I talk about how I come into opposition with black liberals, and a lot of that is fairly
straightforward.
We talk about how the left, and particularly the black left, the black elite leadership
class, how they push all sorts of self-destructive ideologies from undermining the nuclear family
to eliminating standards in education for the sake of equity.
But the black conservative piece was also important because I think a lot of times people think
that all black conservatives want the same things, and there's a group that is really
out for economic empowerment and political representation, and those things are certainly
good things.
But I came into a little bit of opposition to those folks because these were the people
justifying the behavior and the content and the contributions of hip hop artists, rappers
for the better part of 30 years, because they've given X amount of dollars to some charitable
organization.
And for me, the defining piece and defining line in my column is there's no amount of
money that you could offer me that would convince me to sexualize my wife or my daughter
or gangsterize my sons for a willing audience.
And as I said, temptation may come to my family and to our door, but I'll be damned.
And I said literally, if I'm the one that feeds them into the devil's mouth, so I wanted
to make that part crystal clear.
So if we get to the point where the folks on the right, the black conservatives say,
no, we should support X person or X initiative because they point a lot of money into our
community.
But what also comes with that is a degraded self-image that I won't be on board.
Just the same way if conservatives in general, the broader sort of conservative establishment
becomes the party or drag queen story hour.
I'll just set out every election or I'll vote for whoever is the most conservative person
in a given election.
And I won't feel any particular way about it because I'm not here to advance anybody's
political agenda.
As I said in the piece, every group that I name and I also name evangelicals, every
group that I name is concerned with amassing political influence, right?
That's why they always talk about speaking truth to power.
My agenda is to speak truth to error.
I like that line speaking truth to error.
And I think one of the things I've said to people is like, hey man, I'm trying to have
a conversation with black people about because America is having this constant conversation
for entertainment, for ratings purposes, for whatever they have, this constant conversation
going on about black people and about the black community and how we move forward and
how we advance.
I'm trying to specifically say to all people, but black people in particular because that's
the conversation America keeps hosting, is that look, if you embrace the principles held
within the Bible, that's going to move us forward.
Are you not listening to the people that you're teaming up with on the political thing?
They never talk about what the Bible says and what God wants done.
And perhaps that's why we're on this hamster wheel of a lack of success or I don't know
how the destruction of our family, we're not making progress, we're on a hamster wheel,
we're going nowhere because we keep divorcing ourselves from a biblical worldview that they
have framed as racist and conservative.
And so I saw the debates you were having with black conservatives over Twitter and one

from their worldview and they practice a race religion as well.
And anything that we do, anything you might do in correction of us, or are you correcting
white people?
And I sit there and go, well, I'm not white, most of my friends happen to be black even
though I don't care what color my friend, but this is asking someone, are you correcting
the kids in the other house?
Well, those aren't my kids.
And so, man, I love your column.
We haven't, there's some other layers in there that I would like for you to address
out so I'm kind of want to throw the football back to you.
So I think what you mentioned about the biblical worldview is so important.
And I said in the column, a lot of people have heard the phrase that politics are downstream
from culture, right?
So the things that are accepted in culture eventually are going to be codified through
our law and public policy.
But sociology is also downstream from theology.
And what you believe about God ultimately will determine what you believe about man.
And that's why I said one of the groups that I also focus in on are evangelicals.
And when I say, when I use that term, I'm talking about people who would sort of describe
themselves as, you know, biblically conservative.
So these are people for whom the Bible has authority.
They believe that generally speaking that it's inherent and it's infallible, right?
So these are people who, as I said, are both politically and theologically conservative,
generally speaking, black or white.
And they're people in both camps.
And I've just noticed over the years just how they have taken on some of the same positions
as liberal atheists.
These are people who reject sort of the biblical teachings on morality for Marxist teachings
on materialism.
And the way it works out for the black ones is they end up sounding like, you know,
Abram Kendi.
And one person in particular, a guy named Jamartisby, actually works for Abram Kendi.
His whole shtick is about fighting racism.
Every time I see him on YouTube, he's telling white people how to fight racism in their
church.
And in between that, a sprinkle, you know, sort of calls for reparations of one sort or
another.
And even though I think he often gets his history correct in terms of the role that
the white evangelical church has played, either sort of advancing or protecting the status
call as it relates to racism, his present analysis and certainly what it means for the
future is completely off.
Because he takes again the same position that you're either racist or you're anti-racist
in the way Kendi frames it.
And it's important to tie him to Kendi because Kendi is a person who appropriates claims
about Christianity to his own religious dogma.
Kendi believes that racism is death, anti-racism is life.
The Bible teaches that sin is death and that life is found in Jesus Christ.
So when you have an evangelical who serves as a bridge between the church and particularly
black folks in the church and someone like even Kendi, that's important.
And then along with people like Tisby are an entire collection of white knights who
think it's their job to tell the unwashed masses of white conservatives why they need
to say black lives matter and they need to advance the cause of anti-racism.
And my thing is this, I see these people as brothers and sisters in Christ.
The only thing they owe me is what the Bible says that they do, which is to love me as
a brother.
Their version of ethnic paternalism and partiality I have no use for.
I have no use for white guilt.
It is the emptiest of calories.
I can't do anything with it.
It gives me neither energy or encouragement.
So these are people who will write 3,000 word blog posts to explain that when a black man
commits a crime it's because of deep systemic inequity and systemic racism.
But when a white man commits a crime it's because of white privilege and personal defect.
So white people have individual agency but black folks do not.
And it always seems that the people who are called on to rescue the black masses who can't
move forward because of systemic racism are these same white folks.
So all of these groups to one extent or another view the solution to all problems
black people face as bigger government and better white people.
And I reject that straight out.
I have no use for it.
I'm advancing a dark night agenda.
These people are advancing a damsel in the stress agenda.
And as a grown man, the notion that somebody else is going to come along and rescue me
or when they see my kids, their inclination is to pat them on the head and say, I know
how hard you've had it and you're oppressed.
I mean, Jason, if I wasn't saying I would slap some of these people honestly because
not to hurt them but to slap some sense into them.
To say, look, we are both creative beings.
You and I stand toe to toe as equals.
You are not above me.
Your words do not matter more than mine.
Your thoughts and behaviors do not matter more than mine.
Well, for some reason, there are people on the left and the right, black and white,
Christian and atheists who are convinced that a black man who is pro-marriage, pro-family,
anti-degradation, anti-porn, anti-abortion is somehow doing the bidding of white master
pulling the strings behind the scene.
And I just think it's ridiculous.
Delano, I was in an interesting conversation last night with a very good friend of mine
from Kansas City.
I've got some friends in from Kansas City over at my house last night.

I'm trying to, again, honor Jesus with my life and honor these people who have invested in

Jesus has nothing to do with him.
Again, I think he made a sound argument, but I argued back like, hey man, I'm trying to

I got to speak their language in order to shake them up to see the truth of the gospel.
I wanted your reaction.
I think the last part of what you said is an excellent point.
I sort of, I put it, I use the term HSL, right?
Humanity is a second language.

English is a second language.

HSL is the same thing, right?

I'm a dad.
I'm a husband.
I'm a Christian.
Um, you know, I'm a writer.
I'm a thinker.
I'm a son.
